security: The release of the fact that the CIA had a station in Tokyo in the early 1960's would "affect current operations, liaison relationships, assets, Japanese/American relations, etc." The cable also mentions the historical refusal of liaison counterparts to publicly acknowledge the CIA's presence.
summary: This cable discusses the potential release of information about a CIA station in Tokyo in the early 1960s by the JFK Assassination Records Review Board and requests expedited comments from the Tokyo station on how this release would affect current operations and relationships.
summary_one_paragraph: A Secret cable, dated March 23, 1996, from CIA headquarters to the Tokyo station addresses the JFK Assassination Records Review Board's intention to release information about the CIA's Tokyo station in the early 1960s. The cable requests expedited comments from the Tokyo station regarding the potential impact of this release on current operations, liaison relationships, assets, and Japanese/American relations, particularly given press scrutiny of CIA activities in Japan. The cable also references previous discussions with the Board about revealing installations in other countries and asks for arguments, including potential quotes from Ambassador Mondale, to support the station's position in maintaining secrecy.
title: Official Acknowledgement of Tokyo Station
